ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a clot about international law and cooperation that i had not known previously. It gave me a much better understanding of international institutions, geopolitics, and the complexities of our globalized world.
Critical thinking and also connecting theory with practical solutions.
Great knowledge of international politics and why things work the way they do
I learned a lot about international cooperation, as the title of the course may suggest, both at a theoretical and an application level.
How to understand the complicated realm of international cooperation and what institutions and organizations aid or hinder in the success of cooperation.
Gain a foundation of theory and laws/organizations of international politics

Foundational understanding of International relations, game theory, state interaction, the role international laws, organizations, treaties, how different schools of political scientists evaluation the international system, coordination of cooperation between states

Examples of areas of interest that are discussed in depth: Trade, War, Climate Change,  the U.N., ICC, ICJ, health, finance
What is a cooperation problem; how countries resolve cooperation problems using international laws and organizations; international law in different domain areas
I learned just about everything their is to know about international law. It was a great class to develop some game theory and international law theories. Great introductory level class.
I learned about international cooperation, and its successes and failures.
comprehensive overview of various areas of international cooperation, mechanisms and organizations that help resolve cooperation problems

I had never taken a political science class before, so this course taught me both the basics (some game theory, basic economic concepts, cooperation problems) and more complex ideas about how the international system works/should work. I also learned a good amount of 20th- and 21st- century history through the case studies.
I learned about the theories behind international cooperation, as well as about the organizations and institution that govern the international world today.
The foundations of international relations theory, knowledge of global affairs, knowledge of international institutions

You learn a lot about various international organizations and international laws. You learn about various theories to explain international cooperation and judge the effectiveness of international institutions.
Analysis of international cooperation through a theoretical framework
How to define and identify international cooperation problems, and general international relations theories.

The class begins by giving students a strong foundation in the various theories of cooperation, from the generic prisoner's dilemma to the more specific hegemonic stability theory. The latter parts of the course build upon this foundation by going more in-depth in particular areas like health or international law.

I developed insights into the inner workings of international organizations and the complex "science" of ascertaining the likelihood and needfulness of cooperation in a given situation. This was very helpful for evolving my mindset around international development and interactions.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This class probably needed section. We didn't engage enough with the readings we were assigned because there was no space to do that.

Strengths: the professor is very knowledgeable about the content and is always happy to meet with students. 
Weakness: I can't think of one.
Lecture can get boring and feel like its just reading off the slides

Strengths: Not a huge time commitment outside of class, but you still learn a good deal. Professor Pratt is a great lecturer, and the second half of the semester readings are quite interesting.
Weaknesses: Class grade is based on only a few assignments, and the first half of the semester's readings can feel a little more boring (they're more theoretical).
I enjoy the longer lecture format without section. We're able to digest and break down more material .

Strengths: engaging prof, low workload (just readings), straightforward exams
Weakness: only lecture so low interaction, no assignments other than final policy memo and exams so unsure about learning progress

Strengths: class is very well structure, easy to follow, intellectually engaging, classes build off each other, excellent combination of interesting anecdotes and foundational information

Weaknesses: There is so much content that no matter how much you study -- it can be difficult to memorize everything for the exam

Strengths: Interesting content, not a high work load, interesting content; Weaknesses: whole course felt very "distant" -- probably one of the few instances where I would not have minded a discussion section

Strength: the Professor is extremely engaging and has the best way at explaining things. He is such an awesome and relatable person. Although the class was a 9 a.m. it was so fun and I never wanted to miss lecture. 
Weakness: the class is very long. It would be better to maybe go back to the 50 minute lecture classes with a discussion section.
There is a large emphasis on current events and making sure the class material is topical, which is much appreciated.  It is also very well structured.  Not many complaints.

Lectures were all very well-structured and the syllabus was effective in building a foundation on international cooperation as a concept and then building on it with applications of various international issues of cooperation.
I think a more reduced, compact required reading would have been more effective in reinforcing the material.

It would have been nice to get the list of exam topics a little earlier before the midterm and final. A lot of material was covered in the readings and I wasn't sure how much of it I would need to know (in addition to the material covered in class) for the exams until about a week before. I liked the structure of the class; I thought it was organized very well to build upon ideas that had already been introduced. I also liked the mixture of theoretical and historical/current events reading. I do think the class could have been helped by having discussion sections. I didn't know anyone else taking it and I felt kind of alone in studying, but this could also be my fault for not reaching out to people (I'm a first year so I was a little intimidated).

The lectures were engaging and it was helpful that they were online after class. It is intimidating to participate in a 50+ person lecture hall, so maybe more outlets for participation, but I'm not sure how that would be accomplished.

I really like the structural organization of the course and the way we do first half theory, second-half focus on issues. Also, Tyler Pratt is a really good instructor, he explains things really clearly and can communicate his fundamental intuition well. The weakness was just that it was a 9am LOL
This course was very interesting and Professor Pratt is a great lecturer. The workload overall is not too bad, but the readings can be very dense and a lot on some days.

Strengths: 
Very logical progression, easy to follow, relevant to current events

Weaknesses:
Not at 9am!

The organization of this course was fantastic, with the first half of the course building up a definition of international cooperation and very theoretical concepts. The second half of the course focused on applying the concepts from the first half to real-world case studies, which were very interesting and relevant. Each class also began with a discussion of current events. The exams were also incredibly fair, with basic fact recall from lectures.

The format of the slides for the lectures was great and made taking notes in class really easy. The overall structure also ensures students get the most out of every example by providing a theoretical basis first and then moving into the real world.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes.
Yes! Professor Pratt is amazing and the course intersects very well with other courses.
Yes!
Yes! It's not high pressure, the lectures are interesting, and you learn some good stuff.
Yes, if you want a good intro to IR that covers broad landscapes this course is a good selection.
Yes, prof is great so take if interested in international politics at all

I would highly highly highly recommend this class to students of political science, EP&E and game theory as well a students that are interested in social studies but not humanities focused. This class is topical, engaging, well structure, and provides you with a useful understanding of how states interact with each other in the international system and the structures that support them.
Yes, for a major elective or to fill a social science credit. It's not hard and the subject is interesting.
I would recommend this course to other students. For those considering political science as a major this is a great course. It is also an amazing course for stem majors looking for a social science.
Yes!  It is a strong polisci/global elective.  It is generally stress-free and jammed with information.
Yes
yes, for anyone interested in international issues of cooperation

Yes I would recommend this class because I learned a lot of good information about how international politics works. I also got a good grasp on the basic theories that govern the field. It is a good foundational course.

I would! Especially if you're like me and don't have as much knowledge about international relations, we really build it up from scratch  what do states want and why? Why would they do one thing as opposed to another? And what does that mean for cooperation?
Yes! The course content is interesting and Professor Pratt is great!
Yes - this is important for understanding the world of today
Yes! Super interesting content, and good foundation for future international relations courses.

I would recommend this course to a student who has even a passing interest in the topic and can fit it into their schedule. It was one of the most worthwhile lecture courses I've taken and really didn't strain my workload too much.

This was a useful introductory course, and if the student knew they wouldn't have time in their personal life to pursue information about global affairs (as I did), I would recommend this course to ge them started.
